Scorcese Anyone? A Bronx Tale... Well-written, well-directed, kudos to Palminteri and De Niro. However, it swayed away from the plot somewhere in the middle. The part where Calogero met the black girl is unnecessary in my opinion. De Niro should have left this tiny subplot to Spike Lee. Besides that point, there is a constant Scorsese feel throughout the movie, the visually dark beginning (Mean Streets, anyone?), the music and even a bit of the camerawork. But I guess you cannot really blame De Niro for being influenced by Scorsese. This is after all, the Bronx, New York... i.e. Scorsese's playground. On top of that, be reminded that De Niro acted in a few movies by Scorsese with the relatively same theme: Mean Streets, Taxi Driver, Goodfellas, Raging Bull to name a few. De Niro even mentioned in the featurette he did not wanna adopt too much of Scorsese's style. I guess you failed there, Bobby. But you succeeded in making a Class-A movie in your directorial debut. Salute! Oh, I almost forgot. There is a cameo by an Oscar-winning actor, I'm not gonna reveal who. It's NOT Pacino, that's the most I can give. "Well, sometimes in the heat of passion, the little head tells the big head what to do, and the big head should think twice about it." - De Niro in 'A Bronx Tale (1993)

A Bronx Tale of the Devil in a Blue Dress I just received two new dvds: 'A Bronx Tale' and 'Devil In A Blue Dress'. 'A Bronx Tale', starring Chazz Palminteri and Robert De Niro was written by Palminteri and directed by De Niro. It's about a father (De Niro) who became worried when a crime boss (Palminteri) befriends his son. Yeah, I know... when I first read the synopsis, I thought the Palminteri was the father and De Niro was the baddie too. No matter to me, what interests me is that this is De Niro directorial debut. Anyway... I wanna watch the dvd now. Be back soon.

Four New DVDs After 14 days of reservist duties and five days of vacation, I'm back.. worse than before. I bought four dvds from Amazon.com - Once Upon A Time In America, starring Robert De Niro and James Woods; Deceiver, a whodunnit starring Tim Roth and Chris Penn; The Boondock Saints, a funny and entertaining vigilante movie starring Sean Patrick Flanery and Norman Reedus; and Sex, Lies and Videotape, Steven Soderbergh's (Traffic, Ocean's Eleven) first feature film starring James Spader who is absolutely fantastic in this. Once Upon A Time In America is a motherfucking long movie. At 3hrs 49min, it made me feel as if I spent 3 years of my life watching it. It is good and sad but definitely nowhere as good as The Godfather Trilogy or Goodfellas. Its cinematography, breathtakingly perfect is better than Godfather. I really feel as if I've gone back in time. The props and settings are so fucking authentic. To summarise, Robert De Niro and James Woods, beautiful cinematography, nice story, excellent score and a few rape scenes thrown in makes this a good buy. James Woods walks into a room in a bank which he and Robert De Niro are robbing and sees De Niro raping a bankteller and says: "We're going... you coming?" Get it? "Cumming?" Heh heh.. bastards.
